Principles of Macroeconomics

ECON2110G.M01.SP2026 ‚Äì Syllabus

Author

Dr. Meghan Downes

Course Information

Instructor Contact

Dr. Meghan Downes
College of Business
New Mexico State University

Email: cmdownes@nmsu.edu
Office Phone: 575.646.3295
Cell Phone: 575.214.0365
Office: DOM224
Office Hours: BY APPOINTMENT ONLY

Please email to ensure you have my time reserved and available to meet your needs. Office hours will be conducted over Zoom or in-person.

Communication Response Time: I will typically respond to communications within 24 hours.

Course Details

Course Number: ECON 2110G - M01
Credits: 4
Semester: Spring 2026
Duration: January 21 - May 8, 2026 (16 weeks)
Prerequisites: None

Course Meeting Times & Location

Format: Face-to-Face
Location: [Classroom TBD]
Meeting Times: Mondays & Wednesdays, 10:30 AM - 11:45 AM

Important Dates:

  • Classes Begin: January 21, 2026
  • MLK Holiday: January 20, 2026
  • Spring Break: March 16-22, 2026
  • Classes End: May 8, 2026
  • Final Grades Due: May 16, 2026

Course Description

This course introduces students to the principles of macroeconomics, including analysis of aggregate demand and supply, growth models, monetary policy, and fiscal policy. Through a combination of traditional lectures, interactive worksheets, hands-on experiments, and a capstone project, students will develop an understanding of how macroeconomic principles shape real-world policy decisions. The course emphasizes critical thinking, quantitative literacy, and practical application of economic theory.

Macroeconomics is the study of decision-making at the economy-wide level. How do economies grow? What determines price levels and inflation? How do governments and central banks influence economic outcomes? This course explores these big questions through 15 fundamental economic concepts.

Textbook

by Tyler Cowen & Alex Tabarrok
Published by: Worth Publishers

  • eBook (Brytewave App or other digital formats)
  • Rental copies available

Follett ACCESS Program

Required course materials are provided digitally through the Follett Access program at a fixed rate, which is billed directly to your student account when you register for the course. These materials will be available via Canvas on the first day of class. The textbooks can be accessed digitally on the first day through the Follett My Materials link and the Course Materials module.

By enrolling in this course, you have been automatically enrolled in the NMSU Integrated Access Program. This means that your required course materials are being provided to you automatically for this class. The charge for this material has been added to your MyNMSU student account. If you have further questions about Follett Access at NMSU, please reach out to the NMSU Bookstore.

Your Opt-out deadline: 2/6/2026

The opt-out portal closes on: 2/6/2026

Opt-out Portal Link: https://accessportal.follett.com/2218

If you decide not to participate, you can opt out of this program once the opt-out portal opens through the above deadline. Once you opt out, you will be responsible for purchasing the materials listed below on your own. A link to the opt-out portal has been sent to your school mail account from noreply@follett.com and can also be found above.

If you have further questions, please email bookstore@nmsu.edu

Additional Required Materials

  • 3-Ring Binder
  • 3‚Äùx5‚Äù note cards
  • 4 color writing instruments
  • A dumb calculator (NO BLUETOOTH or WI-FI Connectivity, No Programming)
  • Computer with reliable internet connection
  • Access to R and RStudio (free, open-source software)

Course Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  1. Understand Core Principles ‚Äì Grasp fundamental macroeconomic concepts including scarcity, opportunity cost, marginal analysis, and economic thinking

  2. Analyze Economic Data ‚Äì Interpret and evaluate economic indicators, measurements of growth, and changes in price levels

  3. Apply Growth Models ‚Äì Use the Solow model to understand long-term economic growth

  4. Evaluate Macroeconomic Theories ‚Äì Compare and critique Keynesian, monetarist, and other economic perspectives

  5. Assess Policy Options ‚Äì Analyze fiscal and monetary policy tools and their macroeconomic effects

  6. Think Critically ‚Äì Make evidence-based arguments about complex economic policy questions

  7. Communicate Effectively ‚Äì Present economic analysis clearly to diverse audiences

Course Structure & Components

1. Interactive Worksheets (400 points total)

Purpose: Reinforce key concepts through problem-solving and real-world application

Format: - 20 worksheets throughout the semester - One per class session (mostly) - Named format: MMDD-topic-ws.qmd - Example: 0127-scarcity-ws.qmd, 0129-opportunity-cost-ws.qmd

Scoring: - Each worksheet: 20 points - 20 worksheets √ó 20 points = 400 points - Graded on completion, effort, and correctness - Worksheets are completed during class time

Topics Covered: - Scarcity and economic thinking - Opportunity cost and marginal analysis - Quantitative methods and unit analysis - Economic measurement (GDP, inflation, growth) - Growth models (Solow, Keynesian, Monetary, AD/AS) - Policy analysis and applications

Late Work Policy: - Submitted same day: Full credit (20 points) - Submitted within 1 week: Half credit (10 points) - After 1 week: No credit (0 points)

Worksheet Rubric (20 points each)

Criterion Points Description
Completion 8 All questions answered clearly; shows effort and engagement
Accuracy 8 Responses demonstrate understanding of core concepts; calculations are correct
Application 4 Student connects concepts to real-world examples or personal experience

2. In-Class Experiments (100 points total)

Purpose: Develop intuition for economic principles through experiential learning

Format: - 2 experiments throughout the semester - Experiment 1 (Week 3): Marginal thinking and decision-making - Experiment 2 (Week 6): Growth, compound effects, and exponential processes

Scoring: - Each experiment: 50 points - 2 experiments √ó 50 points = 100 points - Graded on participation, data collection, and reflection

What to Expect: - Market simulations and trading exercises - Individual decision-making tasks - Group problem-solving challenges - Real-time data collection and analysis - Post-experiment reflective writing

Participation Requirements: - Attendance is mandatory - Active participation in all phases (experiment, data collection, analysis) - Completion of experiment documentation - Reflection on findings and economic implications

Experiment Rubric (50 points each)

Criterion Points Description
Participation 10 Active engagement in experiment; follows instructions; contributes to group
Data Analysis 20 Accurate calculations; appropriate graphs/visualizations; clear labeling
Interpretation 15 Connects data to economic theory; explains results logically; identifies key insights
Reflection 5 Thoughtful connection to real-world behavior; personal insights; questions posed

3. Economics Notebook (100 points total)

Purpose: Build a reflective practice connecting theory to lived experience

Format: - Semester-long reflective journal - 3 major reflection entries (roughly every 5 weeks) - Each entry: 500-750 words - Submitted electronically in Quarto markdown format

Scoring: - Entry 1 (Due Week 5, Feb 19): 33 points - Entry 2 (Due Week 10, Apr 2): 33 points - Entry 3 (Due Week 14, Apr 30): 34 points - Total: 100 points

Reflection Prompts (Examples): - How has studying scarcity and opportunity cost changed how you think about your own decisions? - What surprised you most about economic growth models, and why? - How do different economic theories help explain a current event or policy debate? - Which economic principle has the most relevance to your future career? - What misconceptions about the economy did you have before this course?

Grading Criteria: - Depth of Reflection (40%): Goes beyond surface level; shows genuine engagement - Connection to Course Content (30%): Explicitly links personal observations to concepts from class - Clarity & Writing (20%): Clear, organized, well-written entries - Evidence of Growth (10%): Shows evolving understanding over the semester

Format Requirements: - Use Quarto markdown (.qmd format) - Include citations where referencing specific course materials - Each entry should be 500-750 words - Include the entry number and date in the header

4. Semester Project: Let‚Äôs Play Policy: Who‚Äôs The GOAT? (200 points total)

Purpose: Synthesize semester learning to develop and present original policy recommendations

Overview: This capstone project asks you to take an economic policy question and develop evidence-based recommendations. You‚Äôll work in groups of 2-3 to create a policy brief and presentation, answering: ‚ÄúWhat is the greatest economic policy approach of all time (GOAT) for addressing this issue?‚Äù

Project Components:

A. Policy Brief (100 points)

A 2,000-2,500 word written analysis including:

  1. Issue Definition (20 points)
    • Clear articulation of the macroeconomic problem
    • Why it matters (economic and social significance)
    • Current state of the problem with data
  2. Theoretical Analysis (30 points)
    • Which economic theories best explain the problem?
    • How do different theories suggest different causes?
    • What does each theory predict about solutions?
  3. Policy Options (30 points)
    • At least 3 different policy approaches examined
    • Pros and cons of each approach
    • Evidence from case studies or research
  4. Recommendation & Justification (20 points)
    • Your recommended policy approach
    • Why this policy is the ‚ÄúGOAT‚Äù (Greatest Approach of All Time)
    • Implementation considerations

Possible Policy Topics: - Monetary policy and inflation control - Fiscal stimulus and recession recovery - Long-term growth and productivity - Income inequality and redistribution - International trade and tariff policy - Financial regulation and stability - Climate change and carbon pricing - Healthcare economics and pricing - Education investment and returns - Immigration and labor markets

B. Presentation (75 points)

A 15-20 minute group presentation including:

  • Content Clarity (25 points): Clear explanation of issue, analysis, and recommendation
  • Visual Design (20 points): Well-organized slides with appropriate visuals and data
  • Delivery (20 points): Confident presentation, good time management, engagement with audience
  • Q&A (10 points): Thoughtful responses to audience questions

C. Peer Evaluation (25 points)

  • Each student evaluates peer contributions
  • Ensures accountability and fair distribution of work
  • Peer feedback affects individual scores

Timeline: - Week 12-13: Topic selection and group formation - Week 13-14: Research and draft development - Week 15: Presentations (May 5-7) - Week 15: Final submissions (May 7)

Format Requirements: - Written brief: Professional Quarto (.qmd) document - Presentation: PDF slides or Quarto HTML presentation - Include references and citations (APA or Chicago style) - All group members must participate in presentation

Grading Criteria for Brief: - Evidence of research (at least 5 credible sources) - Quality of economic analysis (appropriate use of concepts) - Clarity of writing and organization - Originality and depth of thinking - Proper citations and formatting

Grading & Assessment

Overview

Your grade in ECON2110G is based on four types of assessments totaling 800 points. This grading system emphasizes consistent engagement, deep understanding, practical application, and collaborative policy development.

Grade Distribution

Assignment Count Points Each Total
Class Worksheets 20 20 400
Experiments 2 50 100
Notebook Reflections 3 ~33 100
Semester Project 1 200 200
TOTAL ‚Äî ‚Äî 800

Grade Scale

Letter Grade Percentage Range Points Range (out of 800)
A 90-100% 720-800
B 80-89% 640-719
C 70-79% 560-639
D 60-69% 480-559
F Below 60% Below 480

Grading Policies

Late Work

  • Worksheets: 50% credit if submitted within 1 week; no credit after 1 week
  • Notebook Entries: 10% penalty per day late (max 3 days); no credit after 3 days
  • Project Components: Discussed with instructor; typically -10% per day late

Incomplete Grades

  • Granted only in exceptional circumstances
  • Requires written agreement with instructor before end of semester
  • Must be completed within agreed-upon timeframe

Grade Disputes

  • Discuss grading concerns within 1 week of grade posting
  • Come prepared with specific questions or evidence
  • Respectful dialogue and detailed rubrics help resolve disputes

Rounding Policy

  • Final grades are not rounded (92.4% = B+, not A-)
  • Consistent with university policy

Support for Struggling Students

If you‚Äôre earning below 70% at midterm: - Schedule a meeting with the instructor - Discuss challenges and barriers to learning - Develop a plan for improvement - Consider tutoring or study groups - Review difficult concepts in office hours

Additional Resources

  • Writing Center: Help with policy brief and notebook entries
  • Tutoring Services: Math and economics support
  • Disability Services: Accommodations if needed
  • Counseling: Support for personal challenges affecting academics

15 Core Economic Concepts

The semester is organized around 15 core economic concepts:

  1. Treasure Hunt & Scavenger Hunt - Introduction to economic thinking
  2. Scarcity & Limits - Foundational economic concept
  3. Opportunity Cost & Trade-Offs - Making economic decisions
  4. Sunk Cost Fallacy - Avoiding poor decision-making
  5. Marginal Thinking - Incremental analysis
  6. Working with Units - Quantitative tools
  7. Math in Economics - Practical mathematical applications
  8. Measuring Wealth & Well-Being (GDP) - Economic measurement
  9. The Solow Growth Model - Long-term economic growth
  10. The Keynesian Model - Short-run macroeconomic theory
  11. The Monetary Model - Money and inflation
  12. The Dynamic AD/AS Model - Aggregate demand and supply
  13. A Game of Theories - Comparing economic perspectives
  14. Free Markets & Capitalism - Market systems and policy
  15. Let‚Äôs Play Policy (Project) - Applying all concepts to real policy

Course Expectations & Policies

Class Attendance & Participation

  • Regular attendance is essential for success
  • Worksheets are completed during class; missing class means missing points
  • Participate actively in discussions and group activities
  • Inform instructor in advance of planned absences when possible
  • Attendance is mandatory for experiments

Academic Integrity

Students are expected to adhere to New Mexico State University‚Äôs academic integrity standards. This includes:

  • Completing all work independently (unless group work is explicitly assigned)
  • Properly citing all sources used in written work
  • Not sharing completed worksheets or project materials with other groups
  • Violating academic integrity policies will result in penalties up to and including failing the course

Classroom Conduct

  • Arrive on time and come prepared with necessary materials
  • Silence cell phones; minimize distractions
  • Respect the views and contributions of classmates
  • Participate constructively in group work and discussions

Accommodation for Students with Disabilities

Students with documented disabilities who believe you may need accommodations in this class are encouraged to contact:

  • Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD)
  • Corbett Center Student Union Room 204
  • 575-646-6840
  • das@nmsu.edu
  • Contact SSD to discuss your specific needs and available accommodations
  • Accommodations will be provided in a timely manner

Learning Resources

On Campus

  • Library: Extended hours during midterms and finals
  • Writing Center: Support for written work and policy briefs
  • Tutoring Services: Math and economics-specific tutoring available
  • Counseling: Support for personal challenges affecting academics

Online Resources

  • Course website with all materials and schedule
  • Supplementary readings and data sources
  • Office hours (in-person and virtual options)

Communication

Email

  • Response time: 24-48 hours during weekdays
  • Include course number (ECON2110G) in subject line

Office Hours

  • By appointment: Email to schedule
  • Virtual options available

Course Announcements

  • Check Canvas regularly for announcements
  • Important dates and changes will be posted prominently

Course Policies

Changes to Syllabus

The instructor reserves the right to modify the course content, schedule, and policies as needed. Students will be notified of significant changes in advance.

Workload Expectations

As a 4-credit course, expect approximately 12 hours per week of total work (class time + outside preparation).

Technology Failures

  • Save work frequently and maintain backups
  • Technical issues do not excuse late submission of work
  • Contact instructor immediately if experiencing significant technical problems

Final Thoughts

Macroeconomics helps us understand the world we live in. You‚Äôll encounter economic principles in news headlines, policy debates, and your daily lives. This course is designed to give you the tools to think critically about these issues and develop evidence-based perspectives on complex economic questions.

I look forward to working with you this semester!

Contact & Support

Questions? Please reach out:

  • Email: cmdownes@nmsu.edu
  • Office Hours: BY APPOINTMENT ONLY (email to schedule)
